DOC.HEAD: Refusenik Cases to be Resolved, American Jewish Leaders Told
DOC.TEXT: Foreign Ministry officials Thursday told American Jewish leaders at the first national congress of Soviet Jews in nearly 70 years that most of the estimated 100 remaining refuseniks will be allowed to emigrate. Martin Wenick, executive director of the U.S. organization National Conference on Soviet Jewry, said the news about the refuseniks _ those Jews repeatedly refused permission to emigrate _ came from Anatoly Adamishin, a deputy foreign minister. Adamishin told Wenick and other representatives of the U.S. group a ``substantial'' number of the refuseniks who had been barred from emigrating because of access to state secrets would be told soon they could leave. A Western diplomat who follows the refusenik issue said he had heard the same report but cautioned that the Soviets had not officially notified the refuseniks of the news. ``We hope it's true but let's wait and see,'' said the diplomat. Emigration of Soviet Jews has reached record levels under President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's liberalized policies. An all-time high of 55,465 Soviet Jews were registered at a transit center in Vienna between January and November. More Jews left via Romania and Hungary. Refuseniks remain, however, and problems of emigration have been a central topic at the conference of Soviet Jews that began Monday and ends Friday. A draft resolution to be voted on Friday welcomes progress made so far in emigration but says the number of refuseniks has remained stable at about 250 families, 100 of them refused on secrecy grounds. The resolution also criticizes a draft law on emigration and travel as overly vague and says it contains ``infringements on the political, economic and social rights of citizens.'' The meeting was organized by more than 160 Jewish organizations in 75 cities and marked the first time since 1920 that Jewish leaders were allowed to openly congregate to establish a national organization. The country's biggest Jewish group, the Jewish Bund, was founded by Jewish socialists in 1897 but disbanded in 1920. Former refuseniks now living abroad, deputies from the Soviet parliament, and about 150 Jewish leaders from the West were among the 650 people attending the conference. But Soviet officials denied a visa to Jewish activist Natan Sharansky, who spent nine years in Soviet labor camps before emigrating to Israel in 1986. The conference also was scheduled to adopt a resolution saying anti-Semitism is growing in the Soviet Union, and delegates expressed concern about two protest groups that have been demonstrating outside the Cinema Center. As the conference opened, about 60 jeering members of the Russian nationalist Pamyat Society jostled delegates as they tried to enter the hall. They waved signs saying, ``Zionists Out of the U.S.S.R.'' and ``Jews, Get Out of the Union.'' On Thursday, several dozen Palestinian students demonstrators marched outside. They carried a picture of Palestine Liberation Organization chief Yasser Arafat and signs that read, ``P.L.O. Israel No'' and ``Zionism Won't Go Through.''
